roman.name: Ignis
roman.description: Fire (Ignis) was sacred to Vesta, goddess of the hearth, whose eternal flame was tended by the Vestal Virgins. Vulcan, god of the forge, wielded fire to craft divine weapons. Fire represented both domestic piety and destructive martial power.

greek.name: Pyr
greek.description: Heraclitus held fire as the primordial element from which all things arise and to which they return. Prometheus stole fire from the gods to give humanity consciousness and craft. Fire is the element of transformation, will, and creative intelligence.
greek.symbols: Torch of Prometheus, hearth of Hestia

norse.name: Eldr
norse.description: Muspelheim, the realm of fire, existed before creation. The fire giant Surtr guards its borders and will set the world ablaze at Ragnarök. Fire is both the spark of creation (mingling with Niflheim's ice to form life) and the agent of cosmic destruction and renewal.

babylonian.name: Girru / Nusku
babylonian.description: Girru (also Nusku) was the Mesopotamian god of fire, light, and purification. Fire rituals were central to temple practice — the sacred flame illuminated the gods' dwellings. Fire was an agent of divine justice, burning away impurity and falsehood.

vedic.name: Agni
vedic.description: Agni is the Vedic god of fire, the intermediary between humans and gods. He carries sacrificial offerings to the heavens and dwells in every hearth. Agni has three forms: the sacrificial fire, lightning, and the sun. He is invoked more than any other deity in the Rig Veda.

islamic.name: Nār
islamic.description: Fire (Nār) in Islamic cosmology is the substance from which the jinn were created, as stated in the Quran. Fire represents both illumination and trial. The concept of divine light (Nūr) is distinguished from worldly fire, with Nūr representing God's guidance and Nār representing purification through tribulation.

persian.name: Ātar
persian.description: Ātar is the sacred fire of Zoroastrianism, the most visible manifestation of Asha (Truth/Righteousness) in the material world. Fire temples (ātash bahrām) maintain eternal flames that have burned for centuries. Fire purifies, illuminates, and mediates between the human and divine. The Amesha Spenta Asha Vahishta guards this element. To let a fire die is sacrilege; to defile it with impure matter is among the gravest sins.
persian.symbols: Eternal flame (ātash bahrām), fire altar, Asha Vahishta

medieval.name: Ignis
medieval.description: Medieval Christian thought associated fire with the Holy Spirit, divine inspiration, and purification. The tongues of fire at Pentecost symbolized God's transformative presence. Fire was also linked to the choleric temperament — hot and dry — producing courage, ambition, and leadership.

roman.name: Terra
roman.description: Terra Mater (Mother Earth) was the primordial goddess of the earth, mother of Saturn and source of all fertility. Ceres, her granddaughter, governed agriculture and grain. The Romans revered the earth as the foundation of civilization, law, and the city itself.

greek.name: Gaia / Ge
greek.description: Gaia is the primordial earth goddess who emerged from Chaos and gave birth to the sky (Ouranos), the sea, and the mountains. She is the ancestor of all the Titans and Olympian gods. Empedocles counted earth among the four eternal roots of all matter.
greek.symbols: Globe, fruits, key of the earth

norse.name: Jörð
norse.description: Jörð is the personification of Earth in Norse cosmology, mother of Thor by Odin. Midgard, the realm of humans, was fashioned from the body of the giant Ymir. The earth is the middle ground between fire and ice, the place where mortal life unfolds.

babylonian.name: Ki
babylonian.description: Ki is the Sumerian earth goddess, consort of An (sky). Together An and Ki produced the great gods, including Enlil. The earth was considered sacred ground upon which temples (ziggurats) connected mortals to the divine. Agriculture and irrigation were seen as collaboration with Ki's fertile body.

vedic.name: Prithvi / Bhūmi
vedic.description: Prithvi is the earth goddess in Vedic tradition, often paired with Dyaus Pita (sky father). She is patient, nurturing, and bears the weight of all living beings. In the Vishnu Purana, Bhūmi is rescued by Varaha (Vishnu's boar avatar) from the cosmic ocean.

islamic.name: Arḍ
islamic.description: The Earth (Arḍ) in Islamic tradition was created by God as a place of trust (amānah) for humanity. Humans were formed from clay (ṭīn) and are stewards (khalīfah) of the earth. The Quran speaks of the earth as spread out and stable, with mountains as pegs to anchor it.

persian.name: Zamīn (Spandārmad)
persian.description: Earth is guarded by the Amesha Spenta Spandārmad (Spenta Ārmaiti — Holy Devotion), who embodies patience, nurturing, and the sacred ground itself. In Zoroastrian cosmology, earth is one of the seven creations of Ahura Mazda — not inert matter but a living being deserving reverence. The dead are not buried (to avoid polluting earth) but placed in towers of silence (dakhma). Agricultural fertility is a sacred duty.
persian.symbols: Plowed field, Spandārmad, tower of silence

medieval.name: Terra
medieval.description: Medieval cosmology placed Earth at the center of the universe, the densest and lowest of the four elements. Earth corresponded to the melancholic temperament — cold and dry — producing contemplation, endurance, and gravity. The earth was God's footstool, the stage of salvation history.

roman.name: Aer
roman.description: The Romans associated air with Mercury (Mercurius), the swift messenger god who moved between worlds. Jupiter wielded the winds and storms as expressions of divine will. Aeolus kept the winds imprisoned in a cave, releasing them at the gods' command.

greek.name: Aer / Pneuma
greek.description: Anaximenes proposed air as the primordial substance from which all matter derives through rarefaction and condensation. The Stoics elevated pneuma (breath/spirit) as the active principle pervading the cosmos. Hermes ruled the airy realm of intellect and communication.

norse.name: Vindr
norse.description: Wind and air are associated with Odin, the Allfather, whose very name relates to the Old Norse word for 'wind' or 'fury.' Odin gave humanity the breath of life (önd). The vast void of Ginnungagap — the primordial space between fire and ice — is the Norse conception of primal air.

babylonian.name: Enlil / Ilu
babylonian.description: Enlil, 'Lord Wind,' was the Sumerian god of air, wind, and storms — second in rank only to An (sky). He separated heaven and earth and decreed the fates. Enlil's breath was the wind itself; his will shaped civilization and could bring both abundance and the Great Flood.

vedic.name: Vayu
vedic.description: Vayu is the Vedic god of wind and breath, the vital force (prāṇa) that animates all living things. Father of Bhima and Hanuman, Vayu moves between the visible and invisible worlds. In yogic philosophy, prāṇāyāma (breath control) is the mastery of Vayu's element.

islamic.name: Hawāʾ / Rīḥ
islamic.description: Wind (Rīḥ) in the Quran is a sign of God's power — it carries rain, drives ships, and can destroy transgressors. The angels were created from light (Nūr) which is associated with the airy, luminous realm. Air represents the unseen world (al-ghayb) and the spirit (rūḥ).

persian.name: Bād (Vāyu)
persian.description: Vāyu is the Zoroastrian divinity of wind and the atmosphere, operating at the boundary between the material and spiritual worlds. In the Avesta, Vāyu is invoked as both a benevolent force carrying prayers upward and a fearsome power at the threshold of death. The breath (vāyu) connects the soul to the body. At the Chinvat Bridge, the wind carries the soul's fragrance — sweet for the righteous, foul for the wicked.
persian.symbols: Wind, breath, Chinvat Bridge, cypress tree

medieval.name: Aer
medieval.description: In medieval cosmology, Air was the element above water and below fire, corresponding to the sanguine temperament — hot and moist — producing optimism, sociability, and intellectual agility. Air was the medium of sound, speech, and divine revelation; angels moved through it.

roman.name: Aqua
roman.description: Neptune (Neptunus) ruled the seas, and Rome's engineering genius expressed itself through aqueducts that channeled water across the empire. Water was essential to ritual purification and the baths that formed the social heart of Roman civic life.

greek.name: Hydor
greek.description: Thales proposed water as the archē — the fundamental substance of all reality. Oceanus, the great river encircling the world, was the oldest Titan. Poseidon ruled the seas with his trident; the river Styx bound even the gods to their oaths.

norse.name: Vatn
norse.description: Water pervades Norse cosmology: from the primordial ice of Niflheim whose melting created life, to the Well of Urðr where the Norns water Yggdrasil daily, to the Well of Mímir whose waters grant wisdom. Njörðr governs the seas and Ægir brews ale in his submarine hall.
norse.symbols: Well of Urðr, Niflheim ice, Ægir's cauldron

babylonian.name: Enki / Ea
babylonian.description: Enki (Akkadian Ea) was the god of freshwater, wisdom, and magic, dwelling in the subterranean sweet-water ocean (Apsû). Tiamat, the salt-water chaos dragon, represents the primordial ocean from which creation emerged. Water was the source of all life and civilization in arid Mesopotamia.

vedic.name: Āpas / Varuna
vedic.description: Varuna is the Vedic lord of cosmic waters and moral law (ṛta). The sacred rivers — Ganga, Yamuna, Sarasvati — are goddesses whose waters purify body and soul. Water is the element of emotion, memory, and the dissolving of boundaries between self and cosmos.

islamic.name: Māʾ
islamic.description: Water (Māʾ) is the origin of all life in the Quran: 'We made from water every living thing.' Rain is a sign of God's mercy and provision. Ritual ablution (wuḍūʾ) purifies the body before prayer; the rivers of Paradise flow with water, milk, honey, and wine.

persian.name: Āb (Ābān)
persian.description: Water is guarded by the Amesha Spenta Haurvatāt (Wholeness/Health) and the yazata Anāhitā, the immaculate goddess of all waters. Ābān (waters) is honored in the month of Ābān with prayers at rivers and streams. Like fire, water must never be polluted — the Vendidad prescribes elaborate purification for any contamination. Rivers flow from the cosmic sea Vourukasha, where the rain-star Tishtrya battles the demon of drought Apaosha.

medieval.name: Aqua
medieval.description: Water corresponded to the phlegmatic temperament — cold and moist — producing calm, patience, and contemplation. Baptismal water was the medium of spiritual rebirth. The great flood and Moses parting the Red Sea made water central to salvation history as both destroyer and deliverer.
